runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that in this story, the narrator, or person telling the story, visits a tropical rainforest in the country of Costa Rica. Point to Costa Rica on the map. Ask students to share what they can tell about rainforests based on the photos.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to travel through a place to learn more about it.
What are some places you would like to
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find two words with the suffix
that describe a tropical rainforest. (warmest, wettest)
What animals did the narrator, or person telling the story, see in the rainforest? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why did the narrator and Dad need a guide to help them
the rainforest? Why did they explore this place during the daytime and at night?
What is a place that you would like to explore? Explain your answer.
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that this text is a photo comic. It has panels and text boxes like a comic, but it features photos and facts instead of illustrations and dialogue. Tell students that this text explains how trees help keep our air clean.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the comic.
means to keep something from being harmed or destroyed.
habitats for plants and animals. Thats where plants and animals live.
an item that is special to you?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that means the same as
What do forests do with carbon dioxide? Why is this good for the air? Find the sentences that answer these questions.
or protect, Earths forests? What might happen if we do not
What information would you share with people to help them understand the importance of protecting Earths trees?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with the comparative suffixes
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the related words that form phrases in sentences 4, 5, and 6.
Model how to chunk the text into meaningful phrases as you read each sentence. Have students echoread the sentences, replicating your phrasing.

Read the title, modeling appropriate intonation. Point out that the title asks a question. Explain that this is a poem. Point out that the text is formatted in short lines instead of paragraphs. Ask students to point to the rainbow and name the colors they see. Ask students to listen for words that rhyme, or end with the same sounds.
For the first reading, have students echoread the text with you. Then pair students to reread the poem. Partners can take turns reading each couplet.
Prompt students to find words with comparative and superlative suffixes
in the poem and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Point out that the words
but are not examples of words with a comparative suffix. If you remove the letters
there is no base word. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. Point out the exclamation point and explain that you read the title with added urgency or emphasis.
Explain that students will read about a powerful storm called a hurricane. Explain that a hurricane warning lets people know a storm is coming so they can get to a safe place before it arrives.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
means very bad and very serious.
storm, there can be strong winds and heavy rain.
: What might you see happening outside during a
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find a word in the first paragraph with a suffix that helps you understand that hurricanes are
What details show that a hurricane can cause
destruction, or damage? Find sentences that answer this question.
Why is it important for scientists to forecast, or make predictions about,
What would you do to stay safe during a
Then ask them to chorally read it.
suffixes. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 2 (period), 3 (question mark), and 4 (exclamation point).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or an exclamation (read with excitement). Have students echoread the sentences, replicating your intonation.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that this text explains the weather conditions that create wind. It includes a diagram with arrows and labels. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand a series of causes and effects. Point to the arrows on the diagram and explain that the arrows indicate the direction in which the air moves.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they say each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a contest, or competition, between the sun and the wind.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means feeling that you can do well or succeed at something.
that I can teach you how to become better readers.
you can do? What makes you feel this way?
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that describes who won the contest. (stronger)
that he would succeed and win the contest? Find the sentences that answer this question.
How did Wind try to win the contest? Why didnt his plan work? How did Sun win the contest using a more gentle approach?
Tell about a time when you competed in a contest or competition. What happened?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text explains how natural forces change the shape and size of mountains over time.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
means to change in form, shape, or appearance.
: When it rains, a field of dirt may
: What is something in nature you have seen
? How did its shape or appearance change?
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
How are mountains different in size than other landforms? Find the word that answers the question. (tallest)
What are some other examples of landforms? Find the sentence that answers the question.
or change, over time? How can you tell the difference between an older mountain and a younger mountain?
over time, too! In what ways might you change in the next ten years?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
